- more complex derivational morphology.

üö® Grammar nerd explanation üö®
In English, there is a prescriptive rule that you shouldn't end a sentence in a preposition, as in

"It is a preposition that this sentence ends in"

It's a nonsense rule someone made up because "in Latin you can't do this and Latin is more logical". Still it's common. So lots of people would say
"This is the man who I talked to"
rather than
"This is the man to whom I talked"
which the grammar police would want you to say.

When Winston Churchill was told that he shouldn't end sentences in prepositions he famously replied: ‚ÄúThis is the sort of English up with which I will not put.‚Äù (rather than "‚Ä¶ I will not put UP WITH", which every native speaker would in fact say.
